newsitem.title: INDIA: India rice exports seen dipping despite good crop.
newsitem.headline: India rice exports seen dipping despite good crop.

text.p: India anticipates a good rice crop, helped by plentiful monsoon rains, but exports are likely to dip from record levels due to a fall in world demand and uncompetitive prices, officials and analysts said on Wednesday.
"Rice exports are not going to pick up due to a fall in international demand," Anil Adlakha, executive director of the All India Rice Exporters Association (AIREA), told Reuters.
Harvesting of the new rice crop will start in October.
Adlakha said demand for rice on the international rice market is expected to fall to less than 18 million tonnes in fiscal 1996/97 (April-March) from nearly 20 million tonnes in 1995/96.
"Therefore, India will also have to lose a share in the world market," Adlakha said.
Analysts said India was expected to harvest around 70 million tonnes of rice in October, the same as last year.
India produced around 81 million tonnes of rice in the 1995/96 (July-June) crop year, with most of it covering domestic needs. The government has set a target of nearly 80 million tonnes for 1996/97.
"Indian exports this year will be a maximum of three million tonnes as Indian prices are much higher than Vietnam's prices," said Prem Garg, a leading foodgrains exporter.
India exported a record five million tonnes of rice in the year that ended in March. It was largest exporter of rice in the year after Thailand.
Officials said substantial quantities of rice were sold to Indonesia and Bangladesh in the year.
Exports to the two countries are expected to fall this year because their domestic production has improved, Adlakha said.
One Bombay-based commodity analyst said: "Exports are not going to pick up unless prices fall by about 20 dollars."
Traders said Vietnam was selling average quality non-basmati rice at $255 per tonne but Indian prices were around $275.
India, a net foodgrains importer until the early 1980s, has become almost self-sufficient in agriculture since a so-called "Green Revolution" that began in the 1960s.
It has emerged as a net exporter of rice and wheat over the past two years.
Analysts said Indian rice export prices were likely to fall when the new crop arrived. But they said it was too early to say if the drop would be substantial.
Traders said Indian five percent broken long grain, non- basmati rice was quoted at $310 per tonne free on board, 10 percent broken long grain at 300, 15 percent at 280 and 25 percent at 250.
"The monsoon has been very favourable for the rice crop," Adlakha said.
The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) said rainfall in most parts of the country had been normal or above average levels during the four-month southwestern monsoon which started in June.
It was ninth consecutive year of good monsoon rains.
